articles.title: Day 1
articles.description: Digital Academic Identity & Research Project Management
articles.contents:
SESSION 1: Building Your Digital Academic Identity

80 minutes
9:00 - 10:20 AM

üåê Introduction to Digital Identity
15 minutes
Learning Objectives
Understand the importance of digital academic presence in modern research
Identify key components of professional online identity
Recognize the impact of digital footprint on career development
Develop strategies for authentic online representation
Content Overview
What is digital academic identity and why does it matter?
The evolving landscape of academic communication
Platform ecosystem and strategic selection
Building credibility through consistent online presence
Interactive Activities
Digital Presence Audit: Self-assessment of current online footprint
Platform Mapping: Identify which platforms serve different professional purposes
Discussion Forum: Share experiences with online academic platforms
Goal Setting: Define personal digital identity objectives
Key Takeaways
Digital identity is an extension of professional reputation
Consistency across platforms builds trust and recognition
Strategic platform selection maximizes impact

articles.title: Day 2
articles.contents:
SESSION 3: Data Management & Reproducible Research

80 minutes
9:00 - 10:20 AM

üìä Research Data Management Principles
20 minutes
Learning Objectives
Master FAIR data principles for modern research
Develop comprehensive data lifecycle management strategies
Create robust data organization and documentation systems
Understand legal and ethical considerations in data management
FAIR Data Principles Deep Dive
Findable: Metadata standards and persistent identifiers
Accessible: Data repositories and access protocols
Interoperable: Standard formats and vocabularies
Reusable: Licensing, provenance, and quality documentation
Data Lifecycle Management
Planning Phase: Data management plans (DMP) creation
Collection Phase: Standardized procedures and quality control
Analysis Phase: Version control and processing documentation
Sharing Phase: Repository selection and metadata preparation
Preservation Phase: Long-term storage and migration strategies
Practical Implementation
File Naming Systems: Consistent, descriptive, and sortable conventions
Folder Hierarchies: Logical structure reflecting research workflow
Metadata Creation: Essential information for future discoverability
Documentation Standards: README files, codebooks, and data dictionaries
Legal & Ethical Framework
Data protection regulations (GDPR, institutional policies)
Informed consent and participant privacy
Intellectual property and licensing considerations
Collaborative data sharing agreements
Tools & Resources
DMP creation platforms and templates
Metadata schema selection guides
Data repository comparison matrix
Quality assessment checklists
